summary: enteric redmouth (ERM) disease also known as Yersiniosis is a contagious disease affecting salmonids, mainly rainbow trout. the disease can be diagnosed by isolation and identification of the causative agent, or detection of the Pathogen using fluorescent antibody tests, ELISA and PCR assays. the assay was optimised to amplify the yruI/yruR gene. Yersiniosis or enteric red mouth disease (ERM) is a serious systemic bacterial infection of fishes. it causes significant economic losses in salmonid aquaculture worldwide. the disease is endemic in North America and widespread elsewhere. Y. ruckeri is able to form biofilms and grow on surfaces and solid supports in fish tanks, like many bacteria in aquatic environments. yersiniosis has been reported in trout farms where vaccination didn't provide enough protection against the infection. nucleic acid-based amplification (NASBA), loop-mediated isothermal amplification (LAMP) and ramification amplification are available. amplification products can be detected by gel electrophoresis, real time monitoring of turbidity with a turbidimeter. y. ruckeri strains were cultured on trypticase-soy-agar. purity of the cultures was tested with Gram stain. each strain from other bacterial strains was propagated on its specific medium. DNA extraction DNA was extracted from bacterial cultures using QIAamp® DNA mini kit. the loop forward primer LF was used as an Oligo DNA Probe. PCR specific primers IF-2 and IR-2 were used to amplify 1000 bp of yruI/yruR genes of Y. ruckeri [20]. PCR amplification was performed in a 50 l reaction volume with 2 ready mix PCR master mix (thermo Scientific, Hamburg, Germany) amplification was performed in a 50 l reaction volume with a specified amount of template DNA in a final volume of 25 l. gel electrophoresis stained with GelRedTM Nucleic Acid Gel Stain. 10,000 in water (BIOTREND Chemikalien GmbH, Köln, Germany) and then visualised under UV light. a trackItTM 100 bp DNA ladder was used as molecular weight marker. agarose gels electrophoresis stained with GelRedTM Nucleic Acid Gel Stain, 10,000 in water. DNA from non-infected fish tissues and a negative LAMP reaction control were used to detect any non-specific amplification. each strain from other bacterial strains was propagated on its specific medium and then tested by Gram stain and biochemically. DNA extraction DNA was extracted from bacterial cultures using QIAamp® DNA mini kit. cell pellets were re-suspended in 180 l lysis buffer (20 mg/ml lysozym; 20 mM Tris-HCl, pH 8.0; 2 mM EDETA; 1.2% Triton) and incubated at 37°C for 30 min. ethanol was added and thoroughly mixed to yield a homogenous solution. DNA was extracted from tissue samples (liver, kidney, spleen, spleen) the reaction mixture contained 40 pmol each of inner primers FIP and BIP, 5 pmol each of outer primers F3 and B3, 20 pmol of LF (forward loop primer), 1.4 mM of dNTP mix, 1.6 M betaine (Sigma-Aldrich, GmbH, Schnelldorf, Germany), 4.5 mM MgSO4, 8 U of Bst DNA polymerase. amplification was performed in a 50 l reaction volume with 2 ready mix PCR Master mix (thermo Scientific, Hamburg, Germany) the amplification contained (75 mM Tris-HCl (pH 8.8), 20 mM (NH4)2 SO4, 1.5 mM MgCl2, 0.01% Tween-20, 0.2 mM each nucleotide triphosphate, 1.25 U thermoprime plus DNA polymerase, and red dye for electrophor 0.2 mol of low molecular weight PEI was added to the LAMP product after centrifugation for 10 s at 6000 rpm. 0.2 mol of low molecular weight PEI (Wako chemical GmbH, Neuss, Germany) was added to the LAMP product after centrifugation for 10 s at 6000 rpm to form insoluble PEI-amplicon complex. enii, y. intermedia, Y. kristensenii, Aeromonas salmonicida, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Renibacterium salmoninarum and Flavobacterium columnare were tested. DNA from non-infected fish tissues and a negative LAMP reaction control were used to detect any non-specific amplification. a strong green fluorescence was emitted by LAMP positive reactions (F ig. 2, Tube No.3) when exposed to UV light. no fluorescence was evident for a negative reaction. a pellet formed emitted a red fluorescence for a positive reaction. the specificity of ERM-LAMP primers was confirmed by amplification of yruI/yruR gene from all Y. ruckeri tested strains. there are no amplification products detected from other bacterial species, non-infected fish tissues or negative (no template) LAMP reaction control. lane A. sor = DNA from Aeromonas sorbia, lane P. aer = DNA from Pseudomonas aeruginosa, lane R. sal = DNA from Renibacterium salmoninarum, lane NF = DNA from non-infected Fish tissues, lane Y. ruc = DNA from Yersinia ruckeri, lane – veco = Negative control. yersinia ruckeri is a serious infection that causes sever economic losses in salmonid aquaculture. it usually occurs as an acute condition with high morbidity and mortality rates, which necessitate rapid and accurate methods for detection of its causative agent, Y. ruckeri [18]. yruI/yruR quorum sensing system encoding gene of Y. ruckeri was chosen as a suitable target. it controls virulence gene expression through cell to cell communication. yruI/yruR gene was amplified from all Y. ruckeri tested strains by PCR. the calcein in FDR is initially combined with manganese ions. as amplification generates by-product pyrophosphate ions, these bind to and remove manganese from the calcein. this binds to and remove manganese from the calcein, resulting in fluorescence which is intensified further as calcein combines with magnesium ions. Conclusion Loop mediated isothermal amplification assay was developed and evaluated. the assay is rapid, as its result appeared after one hour. it is therefore sensitive than the conventional diagnostic method of ERM disease.
